issue.title: Fedora COPR not updated with 0.4.0
issue.body:
For convenience I use alacritty via the Fedora COPR repository kindly provided by @pschyska , and described in the README. The repository hasn't been updated to provide the latest release - 0.4.0, which provides some much needed fixes for those of us on Wayland.

Are there plans to update that repo, or is an alternative Fedora packaging process needed?

I'm on Fedora 30 and Fedora 31 across several machines (which is why I prefer packages to a more 'manual' approach).

body: Is it actually positioning the window too high, or is it just not rendering any window decorations?

I think it is a positioning issue - if I hit the super key to show the Gnome Activities Overview, the preview of alacritty includes the window decorations (and then when I hit it again, it returns to the incorrect position).

I feel like this might be an issue with Gnome specifically, because of their SSD/CSD approach.

Could you test decorations `none`, to see if the window is still positioned incorrectly or if that "fixes" it (though without decorations showing at all then obviously).
That appears to behave correctly - prompt is at the top, window fills the screen.
BTW - happy to do some more detailed digging/fix attempts if you can suggest where to start looking.

It would be very helpful if you could try the example of https://github.com/rust-windowing/glutin.

You can just run `cargo run --example window` in that repository and check if the issue exists there too.

I had to tweak that example to get it to start up maximised (added `.with_maximized(true)` to the `WindowBuilder` line).

Running that, it does not show the same issue. It starts up maximised as expected, filling the screen, showing the decoration at the top and with not gap at the bottom.

[FYI - this is actually my other machine because I'm at home now, so Fedora 28. Alacritty 0.4.0 is showing the same bug as originally described on here though]

That's very helpful actually, thanks for testing that.

Could you test with https://github.com/chrisduerr/glutin? It's a fork of mine which should run against a more up to date winit version.
Ahhh. That is showing the incorrect behaviour. Something in winit causing a regression then?

> Something in winit causing a regression then?

I'd assume so. I'll report it upstream immediately.

issue.title: Gnome Wayland decorations behind system bar

labels.name: DS - wayland
labels.description: Affects the Wayland backend, or generally free Unix platforms

labels.name: C - needs investigation
labels.description: Issue must be confirmed and researched

repository.name: winit
repository.description: Window handling library in pure Rust

issue.body:
It seems like somewhere between the version glutin master currently uses (0.20.0-alpha4) and the latest master, the window decorations on Wayland with gnome have been broken.

Previously when starting a maximized window, the window bar would be visible, as it should be. However with the latest master, the window is 'offset', so the top of the screen is the top of the inner window (no decorations) and the decorations are behind the system bar.

This might be better explained with the screenshots from the original Alacritty issue: https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/issues/3070

body:
I've reported it upstream in https://github.com/rust-windowing/winit/issues/1312. If you want to help out, checking the exact commit which broke this might help, but it might be good to wait on feedback from the winit people.

If you subscribe to the upstream issue, that should make the feedback loop a bit shorter, then you can answer to them directly.

issue.title: Maximized opened alacritty is mispositioned under Gnome/Wayland. Invisible titlebar.
issue.body:
For bug reports, the following information can help speed up the process. Please describe the bug that you have found and what you would expect to happen instead.

### System

OS: Linux
Version: alacritty 0.4.0
Linux/BSD: Wayland, Gnome

/!\ In `alacritty.yml`, `startup_mode` is set to `Maximized`. The option works perfectly well under KDE/Plasma with X11 or Gnome & X11 for example, but might lead to the following bug.

On Gnome/Wayland, when opening Alacritty, the window gets the correct available size (ie. the size of the screen, less the height of the Gnome-shell bar on the top taken off), but get *positioned* from pixel 0,0 on top left. The result is that the title-bar is not visible and there is an unused space that have top bar's height unused on the bottom. User doesn't have access to the title bar either.

See the first joined screenshot:
![Screenshot from 2020-01-04 11-40-17](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/709500/71764423-033f6c80-2ee8-11ea-9917-3774734e9a67.png)

Another maybe related curious point: title-bar is visible when using the expose feature, but is kinda "eaten up" on the border, see this screenshot:
![Screenshot from 2020-01-04 11-40-25](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/709500/71764440-32ee7480-2ee8-11ea-816b-1b6cd5c996f9.png)
